chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The urgency of this task compels me to thoroughly explain everything I mentioned earlier, with proper discussion and testimony from the Holy Scriptures. The truthful account of both Testaments does not remain silent about everything related to human salvation, so that future deniers have no excuses. Principally, all Scripture, divinely inspired, proclaims one true and only God, the Trinity: the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit, as merciful as He is just.

It is said to Him on behalf of the Church: "I will sing of mercy and justice to You, Lord" (Psalm 101:1). It is also sung of Him: "The Lord is merciful and just, and our God shows mercy" (Psalm 116:5). In another place: "For the Lord is just and loves justice, the upright will see His face" (Psalm 11:7). Again, it is said: "All the ways of the Lord are mercy and truth" (Psalm 25:10). And again: "For the Lord loves mercy and truth" (Psalm 84:12).

In the first commandment of the Decalogue, the same Lord declares Himself just and merciful: "I am the Lord your God, a jealous God, who repays the sins of the fathers to the children to the third and fourth generation of those who hate me; but showing mercy to thousands of those who love me and keep my commandments" (Exodus 20:5). Moses says: "The Lord God is forgiving and merciful, patient and of great mercy and truth, keeping justice and mercy to thousands, removing iniquities and injustices and sins. He will not clear the guilty, bringing the sins of the fathers upon the children and grandchildren to the third and fourth generation" (Exodus 34:6).

Through Isaiah, the Lord also recalls His mercy and justice, saying: "I am God, and there is no other besides me, a just God and a Savior; there is none besides me. Turn to me and be saved" (Isaiah 45:21).
chunks.original_latin:
Sed jam suscepti operis compellit instantia ut omnia
quae superius intimavi, debita disputatione atque
Scripturarum sanctarum attestatione perdoceam. Enimvero utriusque veridica series Testamenti cuncta
quae ad proventum pertinent humanae salutis non
tacet; ut nihil sit quod in posterum contemptor
damnandus excuset. Principaliter igitur omnis Scriptura
divinitus inspirata unum verum ac solum Deum,
illam scilicet Trinitatem, id est, Patrem, et Filium,
et Spiritum sanctum, tam misericordem praedicat
 esse quam justum. Ipsi enim ex persona Ecclesiae
dicitur: Misericordiam et judicium cantabo tibi, Domine
(Psal C 1). De illo etiam canitur: Misericors
Dominus et justus, et Deus noster miserebitur (Psal CXIV 5). Alio quoque loco: Quoniam justus Dominus
et justitias dilexit, aequitatem vidit vultus ejus
(Psal X 8). Denuo dicitur: Universae viae Domini
misericordia et veritas (Psal XXIV 10). Et rursus:
Quoniam misericordiam et veritatem diligit Dominus
(Psal LXXXIII 12). In primo quoque decalogi praecepto
justum se idem Dominus (al Deus) misericordemque
sic intimat: Ego sum Dominus Deus tuus,
Deus zelans, qui reddo peccata patrum in filios, in
tertiam et quartam progeniem, in his qui oderunt me;
et faciens misericordiam in millia millium his qui
 amant et custodiunt praecepta mea (Exod XX 5). Propterea
Moyses dicit: Dominus Deus indulgens et misericors,
patiens et multae misericordiae et verax, justitiam
custodiens et misericordiam in millia, auferens
iniquitates et injustitias et peccata. Et non purificabit
reum, adducens peccata patrum in filios filiorum in tertiam
et quartam progeniem (Exod XXIV 6). Per
Esaiam quoque suam Dominus misericordiam justitiamque
commemorat, dicens: Ego Deus, et non
alius praeter me, justus, et salvans: non est alius praeter
me. Convertimini ad me, et salvi eritis (Isai XLV 21).
